Instructions: Please answer as many of these questions as you can and mail it to Saskatchewan Archives Office, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Sask. where it will be preserved as part of the permanent record of our Province.

Address: Yorkton, B.C. X637
Birthplace: East Flandres, Belgium

We've dug a well and we were always lucky to get good water within 20 feet deep; we dug several wells as we have been on several different farms.

17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner & supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the year and list the members of the family with their ages at the time. State the approximate month, e.g., winter or summer.

Well in the late fall of 1911 at Margo the Indians shot a bear on our homestead we did not get any of that but there was plenty of bush rabbits and partridges breakfast porridge with milk bread dinner potatoes + some meat mostly game bread and butter coffee soup leftover from dinner and soup. Mama was 22 her son was 2 years old another was 31 and Charlie coming 2 i was 31 his brother was 28 another was 31 and Charlie a fine was about 26

18. What year did you serve your first Christmas dinner in eastern Canada?

Give the menu. List those present and give their approximate ages at that time.

I do not remember anything special at a early date. Not like now; a snafu or two a turkey sauces and jellies and a stack of dishes ice cream and pie along a two on the piano to top it off.

19. Were you ever reduced to almost starvation level living on one or two locally produced foods? Give details.

Well the first winter was tough enough. One neighbor about two miles from us told me if it had not been for the prairie chickens he trapped he would have starved. That winter he had also a wife and two children. And I remember when I shot a some thing I could not afford to miss. Now that makes a crack shot out of any body.
16. WRAPPINGS AND CONTAINERS

17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner & supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the year and list the members of the family with their ages at the time. State the approximate month, e.g., winter or summer.

Well in the late fall of 1911 at Mingo the Indians shot a bear on our homestead. We did not get any of that but there was plenty of bush rabbit and partridge. Breakfast: porridge with milk bread - dinner potatoes + some meat mostly game bread and butter coffee soup, leftover from dinner and soup. Mama was 22 her son was 3, my brother was 2, another was 3, and Charlie coming 2. I was 31. His brother was 2, another was 3, and Charlie was about 2.

18. What year did you serve your first Christmas dinner in eastern Canada?

Give the menu. List those present and give their approximate ages at that time.

I do not remember anything special at a early date. Not like now; a roast or two a turkey sauces and jellies and a stack of dishes ice cream and pie, a song or two on the piano to top it off.

19. Were you ever reduced to almost starvation level living on one or two locally produced foods? Give details.

Well the first winter was tough enough. One neighbor about two miles from us told me if it had not been for the prairie chickens he trapped he would have starved. That winter she had also a wife and two children. And I remember when I shot a some thing I could not afford to miss. Now that makes a crack shot out of anybody.
